summary: This is a discovery request letter from Jeffrey Epstein's defense attorneys to the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York. The letter requests preservation and production of documents related to investigations and communications about Epstein across multiple U.S. Attorney's Offices and DOJ components, specifically focusing on the 2007 non-prosecution agreement (NPA) and potential violations of its terms. It signals Epstein's intent to file a motion to dismiss the indictment based on the NPA.

events.title: Non-Prosecution Agreement (NPA) Signed
events.description: A non-prosecution agreement between the Department of Justice and Jeffrey Epstein, which the defense contends constitutes a global resolution of his then-existing offense conduct.

events.title: Indictment by SDNY
events.description: The Southern District of New York returned an indictment against Jeffrey Epstein (case No. 19-cr-00490), which this discovery request is related to.

keyFacts: Epstein's defense team is formally requesting discovery to support a forthcoming motion to dismiss the indictment, arguing it is barred by the 2007 non-prosecution agreement (NPA).
The request seeks extensive communications and investigatory files between multiple U.S. Attorney's Offices (SDNY, SDFL, MDFL, NDGA) and Main Justice regarding Epstein and the NPA.
The defense suggests there may have been efforts to circumvent the NPA by transferring the case from the immunizing district (likely Florida) to another district (New York).
The letter references the civil case 'Jane Doe v. United States' (08-cv-80736 in S.D. Fl.) regarding consultations with alleged victims.

The defense indicates the Northern District of Georgia 'stands in the shoes of the Southern District of Florida' regarding interactions with victims, implying a continuity of office responsibility related to the NPA.
